awd_titl_txt: Tailoring the Nanoenvironment of Diamond-Supported Noble Metal Nanoparticles for Control of Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Professors Jennifer Shumaker-Parry and Ilya Zharov of the University of Utah are supported by the Chemical Catalysis (CAT) program in the Division of Chemistry to develop a new strategy for the preparation of catalysts.  This strategy involves the formation of carefully and precisely structured polymers on diamond surfaces and the use of this modified surface to support precious metal catalyst particles. The low cost, chemical stability, and potential versatility of synthetic diamond are attractive features relative to more common support materials. It is further hypothesized that the structure and properties of the polymer surface modifiers will enhance catalyst stability and allow for control of catalyst reactivity. The knowledge gained from this research is applicable to catalysts made from non-precious metals and support materials and to a wide range of chemical reactions. The broader commercial impact is the potential to create new products and technologies via chemical catalysis. The broader educational impacts are the training of graduate and undergraduate students in an interdisciplinary scientific environment. Specific outreach activities in partnership with the ACCESS Program for women and with a MESA Club stimulate the interest of middle and high school students from underrepresented groups in pursuing science careers. 


The specific aims of the project are: (1) to investigate synthetic nanodiamond as a versatile, robust support for noble metal nanoparticle catalysts and study the growth of polymer brushes on these supports; (2) to explore the effect of the nanoenvironment created by polymer brushes with varying length, grafting density, polarity, structure and chemical composition on nanoparticle stability and catalytic performance, and (3) to study the use of responsive polymers to modify metal nanocatalyst chemistry.  In addition, judicial selection of polymer brush architecture and its control of the catalyst nanoenvironment is investigated to improve catalyst productivity (activity, turnover, life time) and minimize catalyst particle aggregation.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Synthetic nanodiamond is receiving increasing attention because of the thermal, electronic, chemical, and mechanical properties. Our research focused on the mechanical and chemical stability of nanodiamond for serving as a support material for catalytically active metal nanoparticles in a wide range of environmental conditions, including harsh conditions such as extreme acidic or basic solutions. The surface functionalization strategies developed in our research will find broad application in the application of nanodiamond particles as supports for catalysis as well as in modifications of the particles for sensing, electronics, and as materials for temperature control. Surface modification adds utility through attachment of ligands for sensing, molecules for controlling conductivity, and also controls dispersibility in different types of solvent environments for processing as well as applications. The research outcomes have been disseminated to date through three publications, three Doctoral Dissertations, one undergraduate Honors Thesis and nineteen presentations at conferences and universities by graduate students, undergraduate students, and principal investigators. Three additional manuscripts are in development.

The research provides a basis to design stable nanodiamond support materials for catalysis, improving opportunities to efficiently catalyze reactions taking place under harsh or varied environmental conditions. The synthetic diamond nanoparticles serve as low cost, chemically and mechanically stable, and potentially versatile supports for catalytic metal nanoparticles. In addition, the studies laid out the initial steps to control the nanoenvironment for studies of the impact on catalytic activity of nanoparticles supported on nanodiamond supports. The foundational studies will inform development of catalyst support materials to improve efficiency and selectivity of catalyzed chemical reactions and could have broad applications for chemical production.

Multiple approaches to coat the nanodiamond particles with polymers containing a range of functional groups, including a new approach for thiolating the nanodiamond surface, were developed. We demonstrated two different approaches for surface functionalization, a polymer thin film coating and covalent attachment through a multi-step surface-based synthesis. A direct, covalent functionalization strategy for incorporating chemical functional groups on the surface of the nanodiamond particles was developed. These functional groups are handles for growing/attaching metal nanoparticles and ligands for metal complexes

We also worked out a strategy to incorporate catalytically active metal complexes on support materials, both silica and nanodiamond particles. Using very specific conditions, metal ion complexes were formed on support materials and characterization indicated that it is challenging to maintain the metal ion form without producing nanoparticles. Based on the literature, scientists working with metal complexes rarely use electron microscopy to look for the presence of nanoparticles; therefore, particles may be missed, and the metal complex is assumed to be the only active catalytic species present in those studies. The study of the immobilization of palladium complexes and palladium nanoparticles demonstrates the importance of identifying the catalytic species present, making this result broadly applicable in catalysis, especially in the conversion of homogeneous catalysts to heterogeneous catalysts.

In carrying out the nanodiamond functionalization studies, we were surprised to observe the intrinsic catalytic activity of nanodiamond particles. As-synthesized nanodiamond particles exhibited catalytic behavior in the reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol. In studying this behavior, we found metal surface impurities left from then nanodiamond synthesis are the likely acting catalysts.

Because of the interest in using nanodiamond materials for a broad range of applications, the nanodiamond surface modification strategies developed in this research will have impact in a number of disciplines, including biological and chemical sensing, energy, and electronics, as well as general development of composite materials with new properties. Surface functionalization approaches also are often adapted from one type of material to other materials, and thus the methods could be applied to other carbon-based nanomaterials.

The research supported the training of eight graduate students and four undergraduate students. Notably, the group of trainees includes eight women. Students developed a broad range of skills ranging from nanoparticle synthesis, polymer brush growth, analytical surface chemistry characterization, electron microscopy, materials characterization methods, and carrying out catalysis studies, including analysis. All these skills contribute to a specialized workforce that is contributing to different industries, from material development to semiconductor manufacturing. Three graduate students completed Doctoral Dissertations and are scientists in industry, two at Intel and one at reckitt. An additional doctoral student was partially supported and is currently a postdoctoral research associate. Three graduate students completed M.S. degrees and are working in industry. One graduate student is pursuing dissertation research on a related topic. Four undergraduate students completed B.S. degrees in chemistry and chemical engineering. One undergraduate student completed her Honor Thesis, and she is scientist at Myriad Genetics. One undergraduate student worked at Intel, and she is currently pursuing a PhD at Colorado School of Mines. One undergraduate student was awarded a prestigious National Defense Science and Engineering Graduate Fellowship and is currently a graduate student in the Shumaker-Parry lab.


Last Modified: 10/31/2022
Modified by: Jennifer Shumaker-Parry
